tit.cmt: (Ten Demonesses)は、直後に出てくるので不要だと思います。

sen.j: 十羅刹女（じゅうらせつにょ）は、仏教の天部における10人の女性の鬼神。
sen.e: Jurasetsunyo are ten demonesses of Tenbu (group of Protectors of Buddhist Laws) in Buddhism.
Jurasetsunyo are ten demonesses of Tenbu (group of Protectors of Buddhist Laws) in Buddhism.
Jurasetsunyo are ten demonesses of Tenbu (group of Protectors of Buddhist Laws) in Buddhism.

sen.j: 鬼子母神と共に法華経の護法善神である。
sen.e: Along with Kishimojin (Goddess of Children), Jurasetsunyo are Goho zenjin (good deities protecting dharma) in Hoke-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra).
Along with Kishimojin (Goddess of Children), Jurasetsunyo are Goho zenjin (good deities protecting dharma) in Hoke-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra).
Along with Kishimojin (Goddess of Children), Jurasetsunyo are Goho zenjin (good deities protecting dharma) in Hoke-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra).

sen.j: 法華経陀羅尼品に登場する10人の女性の鬼神である。
sen.e: Jurasetsunyo are ten demonesses that appear in Daranihon of Hoke-kyo Sutra.
Jurasetsunyo are ten demonesses that appear in Daranihon of Hoke-kyo Sutra.
Jurasetsunyo are ten demonesses that appear in Daranihon of Hoke-kyo Sutra.

sen.j: なおこの10人の羅刹女には本地垂迹があるとされ、いくつかの説があるが、本文中は『妙法蓮華経三昧三昧耶秘密三摩耶経』の説を一例として出す。
sen.e: These ten rasetsunyo are said to have Honji-suijaku (original reality and manifested traces) and there are several theories; in this article, a theory found in "Myoho renge sanmai samaya himitsu samaya kyo" is described as an example.

These ten rasetsunyo are said to have Honji-suijaku (original reality and manifested traces) and there are several theories; in this article, a theory found in "Myoho renge sanmai samaya himitsu samaya kyo" is described as an example.

These ten rasetsunyo are said to have Honji-suijaku (original reality and manifested traces) and there are several theories; in this article, a theory found in "Myoho renge sanmai samaya himitsu samaya kyo" is described as an example.

sen.j: 藍婆（らんば、ランバー）
sen.e: Ramba (Lamba)
Ramba (Lamba)
Ramba (Lamba)

sen.j: 有結縛と訳す。
sen.e: Translated as uketsubaku (One Who Has Bundles).
Translated as uketsubaku (One Who Has Bundles).
Translated as uketsubaku (One Who Has Bundles).

sen.j: 衆生を束縛し殺害するので名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it shackles living beings and murder them.
It is named as such because it shackles living beings and murders them.
It is named as such because it shackles living beings and murders them.

sen.j: 本地は上行菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is Jogyo Bosatsu (Superior Practice Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Jogyo Bosatsu (Superior Practice Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Jogyo Bosatsu (Superior Practice Bodhisattva).

sen.j: 毘藍婆（びらんば、ヴィランバー）
sen.e: Biramba (Vilamba)
Biramba (Vilamba)
Biramba (Vilamba)

sen.j: 離結と訳す。
sen.e: Translated as Riketsu (Free from Bonds).
Translated as Riketsu (Free from Bonds).
Translated as Riketsu (Free from Bonds).

sen.j: 衆生の和合を離脱せしめんとするので名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it tries to free from unified living beings.
It is named as such because it tries to be free from unified living beings.
It is named as such because it tries to be free from unified living beings.

sen.j: 龍王の如く円満月なり、大海に向かうが如し。
sen.e: The moon is full as Ryuo (Dragon King) and like heading for the ocean.
The moon is full as Ryuo (Dragon King) and like heading for the ocean.
The moon is full as Ryuo (Dragon King) and like heading for the ocean.

sen.j: 右手に風雲、左手に念珠を持つ。
sen.e: It has winds and clouds in the right hand and nenju (rosary) in the left.
It has wind and cloud in the right hand and nenju (rosary) in the left.
It has wind and cloud in the right hand and nenju (rosary) in the left.

sen.j: 衣食は碧録。
sen.e: Its cloth and food are 碧録
sen.cmt: 碧録は読み・定訳不明です。
sen.e: Its clothes and food are 碧録
Its clothes and food are 碧録

sen.j: 面色は白く、前に鏡台を立てている。
sen.e: Its face is pale, standing in front of the mirror.
Its face is pale, standing in front of the mirror.
Its face is pale, standing in front of the mirror.

sen.j: 本地は無辺行菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is Muhengyo Bosatsu (Limitless Practice Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Muhengyo Bosatsu (Limitless Practice Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Muhengyo Bosatsu (Limitless Practice Bodhisattva).

sen.j: 曲歯（こくし、クータ・ダンティー）
sen.e: Kokushi (Kutadanti) or Crooked Teeth
Kokushi (Kutadanti) or Crooked Teeth
Kokushi (Kutadanti) or Crooked Teeth

sen.j: 施積と訳す。
sen.e: Translated as seshaku (One Who Donates Piles).
Translated as seshaku (One Who Donates Piles).
Translated as seshaku (One Who Donates Piles).

sen.j: 歯牙が上下に曲がり甚だ畏怖すべきゆえに名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it has a threatening look with crooked teeth.
It is named as such because it has a threatening look with crooked teeth.
It is named as such because it has a threatening look with crooked teeth.

sen.j: 本地は浄行菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is Jogyo Bosatsu (Pure Practice Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Jogyo Bosatsu (Pure Practice Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Jogyo Bosatsu (Pure Practice Bodhisattva).

sen.j: 華歯（けし、プシュパ・ダンティー）
sen.e: Keshi (Pushpadanti) or Flowery Teeth
Keshi (Pushpadanti) or Flowery Teeth
Keshi (Pushpadanti) or Flowery Teeth

sen.j: 歯牙が上下に鮮明に並んでいるため名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it has perfect teeth.
It is named as such because it has perfect teeth.
It is named as such because it has perfect teeth.

sen.j: 本地は安立行菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is Anryugyo Bosatsu.
Its original reality is Anryugyo Bosatsu.
Its original reality is Anryugyo Bosatsu.

sen.j: 黒歯（こくし、マクタ・ダンティー）
sen.e: Kokushi (Makutadanti) or Black Teeth
Kokushi (Makutadanti) or Black Teeth
Kokushi (Makutadanti) or Black Teeth

sen.j: 歯牙が黒く畏怖すべきゆえに名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it has a threatening look with black teeth.
It is named as such because it has a threatening look with black teeth.
It is named as such because it has a threatening look with black teeth.

sen.j: 本地は釈迦如来。
sen.e: Its original reality is Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni).
Its original reality is Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni).
Its original reality is Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni).

sen.j: 多髪（たはつ、ケーシニー）
sen.e: Tahotsu (Keshini) or Much Hair
Tahotsu (Keshini) or Much Hair
Tahotsu (Keshini) or Much Hair

sen.j: 髪の毛が多いので名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it has a thick head of hair.
It is named as such because it has a thick head of hair.
It is named as such because it has a thick head of hair.

sen.j: 本地は普賢菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is Fugen Bosatsu.
Its original reality is Fugen Bosatsu.
Its original reality is Fugen Bosatsu.

sen.j: 無厭足（むえんぞく、ラークシャシャ・チャラー）
sen.e: Muenzoku (Achala) or Insatiable
Muenzoku (Achala) or Insatiable
Muenzoku (Achala) or Insatiable

sen.j: 衆生を殺害しても厭わない、飽き足らないことから名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it couldn't care less about killing living beings or never be satisfied.
It is named as such because it couldn't care less about killing living beings or ever being satisfied.
It is named as such because it couldn't care less about killing living beings or ever being satisfied.

sen.j: 本地は文殊師利菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is monjushuri bosatsu.
Its original reality is monjushuri bosatsu.
Its original reality is monjushuri bosatsu.

sen.j: 持瓔珞（じようらく、マーラー・ダーリー）
sen.e: Jiyoraku (Maladhari) or Necklace Bearer
Jiyoraku (Maladhari) or Necklace Bearer
Jiyoraku (Maladhari) or Necklace Bearer

sen.j: 手に瓔珞を持つため名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it has a necklace in its hand.
It is named as such because it has a necklace in its hand.
It is named as such because it has a necklace in its hand.

sen.j: 本地は観世音菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is Kanzeon Bosatsu (the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy).
Its original reality is Kanzeon Bosatsu (the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy).
Its original reality is Kanzeon Bosatsu (the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy).

sen.j: 皇諦（こうだい、クンティー）
sen.e: Kodai (Kunti)
Kodai (Kunti)
Kodai (Kunti)

sen.j: 何所（かしょ）と訳す。
sen.e: Translated as kasho.
Translated as kasho.
Translated as kasho.

sen.j: 天上と人間の世界を自在に往来するゆえに名づく。
sen.e: It is named as such because it can come and go between the heaven and the human world.
It is named as such because it can come and go between heaven and the human world.
It is named as such because it can come and go between heaven and the human world.

sen.j: 法華十羅刹女法には、膝を立てて座り、右手に裳（も）、左手に独鈷を持つ。
sen.e: In Hokke Jurasetsunyo Ho, it sits with its knees up and has mo (long pleated skirts) in the right hand and tokko (a religious tool like a short stick) in the left.
In Hokke Jurasetsunyo Ho, it sits with its knees up and has mo (long pleated skirts) in the right hand and tokko (a religious tool like a short stick) in the left.
In Hokke Jurasetsunyo Ho, it sits with its knees up and has mo (long pleated skirts) in the right hand and tokko (a religious tool like a short stick) in the left.

sen.j: 本地は弥勒菩薩。
sen.e: Its original reality is Miroku Bosatsu (Maitreya Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Miroku Bosatsu (Maitreya Bodhisattva).
Its original reality is Miroku Bosatsu (Maitreya Bodhisattva).

sen.j: 奪一切衆生精気（だついっさいしゅじょうしょうげ、サルヴァ・サットヴァ・オージョーハーリー）
sen.e: Datsu Issaishujo Shoke (Sarvasattvojohari) or Robber of the Vital Spirit of All Living Beings
Datsu Issaishujo Shoke (Sarvasattvojohari) or Robber of the Vital Spirit of All Living Beings
Datsu Issaishujo Shoke (Sarvasattvojohari) or Robber of the Vital Spirit of All Living Beings

sen.j: 一切の衆生の精気を奪うため名づく。
sen.e: It is called as such because it takes the vital spirit of all living beings.
It is called as such because it takes the vital spirit of all living beings.
It is called as such because it takes the vital spirit of all living beings.

sen.j: 本地は多宝如来。
sen.e: Its original reality is Taho Nyorai (Buddha of Many Treasures).
Its original reality is Taho Nyorai (Buddha of Many Treasures).
Its original reality is Taho Nyorai (Buddha of Many Treasures).

sen.j: 法華経では、これらの鬼神が釈迦から法華経の話を聞いて成仏できることを知り、法華経を所持し伝える者を守護することを誓っている。
sen.e: In the Lotus Sutra, Buddha told a story of Hokekyo that made these demonesses realize that they could attain Buddhahood, and they swore to protect those who possess and hand down the Hokekyo.
In the Lotus Sutra, Buddha told a story of Hokekyo that made these demonesses realize that they could attain Buddhahood, and they swore to protect those who possess and hand down the Hokekyo.
In the Lotus Sutra, Buddha told a story of Hokekyo that made these demonesses realize that they could attain Buddhahood, and they swore to protect those who possess and hand down the Hokekyo.

sen.j: 羅刹女の名前と数は、上記とは異なる名前が登場する十大羅刹女もある。
sen.e: Regarding to the names and the numbers of Jurasetsunyo, there are other Jurasetsunyo with different names.
Regarding to the names and the numbers of Jurasetsunyo, there are other Jurasetsunyo with different names.
Regarding to the names and the numbers of Jurasetsunyo, there are other Jurasetsunyo with different names.

sen.j: また八大羅刹女や十二大羅刹女、また孔雀経の七十二羅刹女といった名称がそれぞれ挙げられている。
sen.e: There are also eight and twelve rasetsunyo or seventy-two rasetsunyo in Kujaku kyo (sutra).
There are also eight and twelve rasetsunyo or seventy-two rasetsunyo in Kujaku kyo (sutra).
There are also eight and twelve rasetsunyo or seventy-two rasetsunyo in Kujaku kyo (sutra).

sen.j: ただし、法華経に見られる羅刹女の名称については法華経陀羅尼品以前の出所が不明であり、研究の対象になっている。
sen.e: It should be noted, however, that the source of the names of rasetsunyo in Hokekyo prior to before Hokekyo Daranihon is unknown and it is the subject of study.
It should be noted, however, that the source of the names of rasetsunyo in Hokekyo prior to before Hokekyo Daranihon is unknown and it is the subject of study.
It should be noted, however, that the source of the names of rasetsunyo in Hokekyo prior to Hokekyo Daranihon is unknown and it is the subject of study.

sen.j: なお、梵本の法華経を日本語に訳した岩本裕によると、他の仏典にもラクシャシー（羅刹女）、あるいはヤクシニー（夜叉女）としてランバーなどの名も散見されると報告しており、（ランダムに列挙されたのみで）文化史的には特別な意義あるものではないという。
sen.e: According to Yutaka Iwamoto who translated Sanskrit texts of Hokekyo into Japanese, Lamba appears as Rakusasi or Yaksni in other Buddhist scriptures, indicating that the names of Jurasetsunyo are only listed at random and thus they are not significant in the cultural history.

According to Yutaka Iwamoto who translated Sanskrit texts of Hokekyo into Japanese, Lamba appears as Rakusasi or Yaksni in other Buddhist scriptures, indicating that the names of Jurasetsunyo are only listed at random and thus they are not significant in the cultural history.

According to Yutaka Iwamoto who translated Sanskrit texts of Hokekyo into Japanese, Lamba appears as Rakusasi or Yaksni in other Buddhist scriptures, indicating that the names of Jurasetsunyo are only listed at random and thus they are not significant in the cultural history.
